channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Why Russia Stole Potemkin’s Bones From Ukraine
item.description: The 18th-century military commander and lover of Catherine the Great helped conquer Ukraine and looms large in the version of history the Kremlin uses to justify the war.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Fine Art Images/Heritage Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A portrait of Prince Grigory Aleksandrovich Potemkin.

item.title: Pentagon’s Strategy Says China and Russia Pose More Dangerous Challenges
item.description: A new document describes the military’s response to a new era in broad terms and guides Pentagon policy and budget decisions, but it lacks details.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. troops in Fort Bragg, N.C., prepared to deploy to Eastern Europe in early February in response to the crisis in Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Program Aims to Keep Sensitive Weapons in Ukraine
item.description: Portable, lethal and high-tech munitions like Stinger and Javelin missiles are a focus of a monitoring program operating from the embassy in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and John Ismay
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: An American volunteer teaching Ukrainian soldiers how to use a Javelin at a base outside Zaporizhzhia in South Eastern Ukraine.

item.title: US Economy Grew at 2.6% Annual Rate in Q3, GDP Report Shows
item.description: Gross domestic product increased 0.6 percent after two quarters of decline, but key components continue to show an economic slowdown.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: US Mortgage Rates Soar Past 7% for the First Time Since 2002
item.description: The average rate on 30-year mortgages — the most popular kind among Americans — rose to the highest level since 2002, tracking the Federal Reserve’s aggressive campaign of rate increases.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, the most popular kind among U.S. home buyers, rose to 7.08 percent on Thursday.

item.title: War in Ukraine Likely to Speed, Not Slow, Shift to Clean Energy, I.E.A. Says
item.description: While some nations are burning more coal this year in response to natural-gas shortages spurred by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, that effect is expected to be short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Martin Meissner/Associated Press
item.media:description: Sheep grazing in front of a coal-fired power plant and wind turbines near Luetzerath, Germany, in October, 2022.

item.title: Europe’s Energy Crisis Is Sending Leaders to Africa for Help
item.description: Officials from Algeria to Mozambique say they hope to take advantage of an abrupt change in a long-unequal relationship.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Melissa Eddy and Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Andreas Rinke/Reuters
item.media:description: President Macky Sall of Senegal welcomed the German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, in May.

item.title: Climate Protester Glues His Head to ‘Girl With a Pearl Earring’ Painting
item.description: The artwork by Johannes Vermeer, exhibited in The Hague, was the latest artwork to be targeted by protesters concerned about climate change. One person glued his head to the painting and another glued his hand to the wall.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Lex Van Lieshout/Agence France-Presse, via Anp/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Johannes Vermeer’s painting “Girl with a Pearl Earring” joins Vincent van Gogh’s “Sunflowers” and Claude Monet’s “Grainstacks” as paintings targeted by climate activists.

item.title: As J.D. Vance Courts Ohio, His Fealty to Trump Proves Double-Edged
item.description: The Republican Senate candidate changed his tune on Donald Trump and now has his endorsement, but a remark by the former president about Vance’s fealty is dogging him in Ohio.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: J.D. Vance and Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina meeting with supporters at a campaign event in Beavercreek, Ohio.

item.title: Black Democrats Say the Party Isn’t Helping Beasley and Demings Enough
item.description: As Cheri Beasley and Val Demings run competitive Senate campaigns in North Carolina and Florida, some Black female Democrats say party leaders are leaving them to fend for themselves.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Representative Val Demings has put up a strong challenge to Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a state that has tilted toward Republicans in recent years.

item.title: How Mike Lindell’s Pillow Business Propels the Election Denial Movement
item.description: Many American entrepreneurs have mixed politics and business. No one has fused the two quite like the chief executive of MyPillow.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Berzon, Charles Homans and Ken Bensinger
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mike Lindell, the MyPillow chief executive, at a Trump rally this month in Arizona.

item.title: Chip Makers, Once in High Demand, Confront Sudden Challenges
item.description: Demand for semiconductors was off the charts last year. But a sharp slowdown coupled with new U.S. restrictions against China have created obstacles.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark
item.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
item.media:description: A Micron plant. U.S. chip makers have pledged huge expansions in domestic manufacturing, betting on a growing need for their products and the prospects of federal subsidies.

item.title: Stand-Up Comics and the Parent Trap
item.description: Specials from Nick Kroll, Hasan Minhaj and other young dads and moms show just how difficult it is to mine fresh insights from such worked-over terrain.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: OB-GYN Residency Programs Face Tough Choice on Abortion Training
item.description: Many residency programs for obstetricians and gynecologists are in a risky position, caught between state abortion bans and accreditation requirements.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Morgan Hornsby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Nikki Zite, a professor at a University of Tennessee OB-GYN residency program, worries that top-tier candidates will not apply there because abortions cannot be performed in the state.

item.title: Covid, Flu and RSV Are Increasing Hospitalizations in NYC
item.description: New Yorkers are falling ill with new variants of Covid and old illnesses like flu and RSV that masking and other precautions once held at bay.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: New Yorkers waited for Covid bivalent booster shots at Bellevue Hospital this fall.

item.title: Covid Symptoms Can Rebound Even If You Don’t Take Paxlovid
item.description: A new study found that more than a third of those who recovered from an infection had symptoms recur days or weeks later.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Rebound symptoms are common, said one doctor. “It doesn’t mean that things are going south,” he said. “It’s just the natural way the disease goes.”

item.title: Republicans Have No Inflation Plan
item.description: In fact, G.O.P. policies would make inflation worse.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times

item.title: What Kanye West’s Antisemitism Reveals
item.description: Kanye West’s bigotry should start an honest conversation about the reach of antisemitism.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Mark J. Rebilas/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

item.title: The Republican Double Standard That’s Endangering American Democracy
item.description: Heads, Republicans win. Tails, Democrats cheated.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni
item.media:credit: Ben Wiseman

item.title: Nikolas Cruz, the Parkland Shooter, Deserved the Death Penalty
item.description: Retribution can help restore a moral balance.
item.dc:creator: Robert Blecker
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mike Stocker, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Hui Wang, whose son, Peter, was killed by Nikolas Cruz at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., after the jury rejected a death sentence for Mr. Cruz.

item.title: The Climate’s Improved Future
item.description: The world has made real progress on climate change.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Walker Pickering for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wind turbines in Western, Neb.

item.title: Is New York (of All Places) About to Go Red?
item.description: Two weeks before Election Day, races across the state have gotten too close for Democrats’ comfort.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Stella Tan, Sydney Harper, MJ Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mary Altaffer
item.media:description: A televised New York governor’s race debate this week. The race, among others in New York State, are closer than many Democrats expected.

item.title: Inside the Minds of Four Grassroots Conservative Voters
item.description: Inside the minds of four American conservative voters, whose political priorities revolve around defending the country.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

item.title: A Times Event: How Will World Leaders Address Climate Change?
item.description: Join the head of the World Trade Organization and other global leaders for a livestream of The New York Times Climate Forward event from Egypt.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Man Who Dragged Officer Into Jan. 6 Mob Is Sentenced to 90 Months
item.description: The sentence for the defendant, Albuquerque Cosper Head, was one of the most severe penalties handed down so far in the Justice Department’s investigation of the Capitol attack.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mob surrounding the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: Somalia Asks US to Step Up Drone Strikes Against Qaeda-Linked Fighters
item.description: A new administration in Somalia has launched an offensive against Al Shabab, which are also facing an uprising from local militias.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Farah Abdi Warsameh/Associated Press
item.media:description: Shabab fighters outside Mogadishu, Somalia, in 2008. The Somali government wants U.S. military operators to be able to attack groups of Shabab militants who might pose a threat to Somali forces.

item.title: When Meteors Shook Mars, NASA Was Listening and Watching
item.description: Scientists thought the InSight spacecraft had recorded some major marsquakes, but with another NASA mission’s help, they found what had really shaken up the red planet.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: NASA
item.media:description: The white spots are water ice that was kicked up by a meteor impact on Mars last December. The crater is about 500 feet wide.

item.title: Israeli-Lebanese Maritime Deal Marks a Milestone, With Limitations
item.description: The U.S.-brokered deal has stirred fierce debate in Israel between some who view it as an achievement and others as a dangerous capitulation.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Jack Guez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Lebanese patrol boats in the Mediterranean Sea on Thursday.

item.title: How to Prepare for Daylight Saving Time
item.description: Earlier mornings and shorter evening light can be a tough adjustment. But there are ways to prepare for the end of daylight saving.
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns
item.media:credit: Linda Merad

item.title: How to Get Back Into Running After a Long Break
item.description: Whether you’re lacing up your running shoes after a few months or a few years, follow these tips to avoid injury and frustration.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Landon Speers for The New York Times

item.title: The Worst Foods and Drinks for Your Teeth
item.description: When assessing how likely a given meal, snack or drink is to harm your dental health, there are two main things to consider, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Kelsey McClellan for The New York Times

item.title: Is It Covid or the Flu? How to Tell Symptoms Apart
item.description: There are slight differences in symptoms, but the best way to tell which infection you have is through a test.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: How to ‘Romanticize Your Life’
item.description: A trend that took off early in the pandemic encourages people to appreciate life’s simple pleasures, a philosophy that resonates just as strongly two years later.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Moritz Wienert

item.title: Henry Selick and Jordan Peele Team Up on ‘Wendell & Wild’
item.description: The stop-motion animator and the horror writer-director collaborated on the screenplay for Selick’s latest darkly comic fable “Wendell & Wild.”
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
